Hi again,

So I was working a bit on my orbital construction project and accidentally sent up a shuttle at the worst possible time cause I was tired and not paying enough attention. I only had 3 days of life support (TAC), but there's plenty of supplies on the station, so all I had to do was dock before running out.

My shuttle is WAY ahead of the station, practically on the other side of the planet, but on a nearly identical inclination. With the help of Kerbal Alarm Clock, I discovered that I could make rendezvous in under 3 days, but only if my orbit was an average 65 km higher than the station. This is a much more aggressive profile than I've ever tried before, and I'm having some trouble knowing when to lower my periapse to get the best close approach possible. Ideally, I'd like to get closest approach half an orbit later and lower my apoapse down, thereby zeroing my relative velocity at closest approach. This is all correct right?

Anyway, what rules of thumb can I use to tell when to lower PE for this kind of approach? Really any advice on how to do a fast, efficient rendezvous would be great.

What I would do:

1.) Match orbit with the station. AP and PE as identical as possible.

2.) Burn to raise your apoapsis.

3.) Stop burning when you magically get an encounter.

4.) Finetune to less than 2km close approach distance.

How does it work? Because you first matched orbits, that means that your periapsis after the burn remains touching the station's orbit. All that is left to do then is to delay your time to periapsis to such a degree that the station has time to arrive at the same spot. And that's what raising your apoapsis does.

You will have a hard braking burn during your encounter, because you will be going significantly faster at periapsis than the station. But that's not a problem if your closest encounter is under 2km. At that point, you can simply set your navball to target mode and burn at the retrograde marker untill your relative velocity is zero. Then just point your nose at the station and fly towards it. At this close distance, the difference in orbits is no longer large enough to disrupt your approach in any meaningful way.

Note 1: while this is the fastest way, it's also the most dV costly.

Note 2: This approach works even when your inclination isn't matched, as long as you perform your AP raising burn at the ascending or descending node. You will then have a chance at AP (which will correspond to the opposing node to where you burned) to match inclination cheaply.

Note 3: For high orbits, you can achieve the same result by lowering your periapsis instead of raising your apoapsis, and this is even faster. But I'm assuming you're in LKO, where dropping your periapsis far enough for this to work is not an option because atmosphere.

Edited August 14, 2015 by Streetwind

ad 1) to be more delta-V conservative.

Instead of burning outright, set up two maneuver nodes: one at the periapsis, another a little bit after it.

Raise the apoapsis using the first node *a bit*, something like 20%. 100-200km.

Leave the second node "null"/"no-op" (0 dV). Click the ting blue "+" icon (on the view of the node where the red X to delete it appears) on the second node to increase number of orbits it applies to. The encounter points will be getting closer. Keep clicking until the markers are closest.

Now use prograde/retrograde and normal/antinormal on the second node to perfect the encounter.

Check the encounter time. If it's above the desired 3 days, increase apoapsis of the first node more. But it shouldn't be - LKO orbits are of order of 32 minutes and you should get an encounter within some 10 orbits.

I also advice using Precise Node.

Managed to launch and rendezvous in something like 10-15 minutes with a Dreamchaser style craft never tried before, without waiting even a single orbit

A very important thing is to launch when the target is a bit before the KSC position ( if you have KER, I'd say 220Ã‚Â°-225Ã‚Â° angle )

The greater the difference in altitude between your station's orbit and your shuttle's "phasing orbit" the quicker the lower will catch up with the higher. I'd never bother to wait days (!) in LKO for a rendezvous, using a at least 75km separation in LKO (75km/150km). Changes to orbital altitude of these magnitudes only take about 100m/s dV and usually mean docking within a few hours rather than days. Look at it this way - in less than three days you could do a flyby of Mun and more or less pick where on the station's orbit you want to rendezvous rather than just waiting for 'the' right time. On the other hand, of course, that's closer to 1km/s dV so I don't recommend it (although this would make sense if you needed to do a big plane-change at the same time).

When to burn, it all depends on the phase angle between the vehicles (just like optimal interplanetary transfers). Using rough figures for my example orbit altitudes:

First find the orbital periods:

75km, orbital period = 31m

150km, orbital period = 36m

The transit during a Hohmann transfer for rendezvous will take half an orbit, or half the average time of the two orbital periods:

Average orbital period = 33.5m

Transit time = (33.5m / 2) 16.75m

(Transfer dV = ~59m/s * 2 = 118m/s)

So, if you're transferring the lower-orbit vehicle to the higher target:

The target will complete (16.75m / 36m) 0.47 of its orbit during your transit

Which means you want to start when the target is (0.47 * 360) 167.5 degrees from the rendezvous-point

Or, more simply, (180 - 167.5) 12.5 degrees ahead of you

Alternatively, transferring the higher-orbit vehicle to the lower target:

The target will complete (16.75m / 31m) 0.54 of its orbit during your transit

Which means you want to start when the target is (0.54 * 360) 194.5 degrees from the rendezvous-point

Or, more simply, (194.5 - 180) 14.5 degrees behind you

And if I hadn't used such rough figures we might have got 13.5 degrees for both of them, but what the hell - who can 'see' 13.5 degrees by eye?! 15 degrees (1/6th of 90 degrees) is close enough and not too hard to judge by eye, so create the manoeuvre node for there and jiggle it until it fits (technical term).

[sorry Slashy, but sometimes I'd rather look and see if it's close-enough than do the maths properly.]

Of course, this might just be an easyish way for me because I'm a navigator and used to picturing 90 degrees, 60 degrees, 45 degrees, 30 degrees, 15 degrees (the difference between 45 and 30 also being 15)

[sorry Slashy, but sometimes I'd rather look and see if it's close-enough than do the maths properly.]

Pecan,

I about did a spit- take when I saw you had mentioned me

Actually, that's about how I do it as well. I don't bother with the math during the execution phase because (as you point out) maneuver nodes do that. The number- crunching is just for mission planning and ship design. AKA "Where it's helpful". I'm way too lazy to compute stuff I don't need to compute

Thanks for the chuckle (must spread some rep around)

-Slashy
